November 17, 2019 at 9:32 PM ·

The Hood River County Sheriff's Office and the Hood River County School District worked together over the weekend to investigate a threat towards a HRCSD school that was posted on social media. All threats towards our schools are treated as credible until we have evidence to say otherwise. In this case, the person responsible was extremely cooperative and recognized that their careless words had a large impact.

The Hood River County School District sent an auto call out to Hood River Middle School and Hood River Valley High School parents and information from the call is posted on the School District website.

HRCSO would like to encourage parents and students alike to always alert law enforcement immediately when threats are made, whether they feel it to be credible or not. Please talk to your students about their role in keeping their schools safe, as well as the appropriate use of social media.

post_text: Do you remember this heartwarming story? The rock star Hood River Valley High School girls' soccer team will need a coach next year. Could it be you or someone you know?
shared_text:
Hood River County School District is feeling proud at Columbia River Gorge.
December 4, 2018 at 2:50 PM ·

As we're seeing Gorge roads and trails open back up, here is a heartfelt story from behind the scenes.

Last year, the Hood River Valley High School girls' soccer match with Hillsboro High was rescheduled due to smoke from the Eagle Creek Fire. At the rescheduled match, Hillsboro surprised our team with a $500 donation to help our community rebuild post fire. Kevin Haspela, our soccer coach, then challenged our girls to double the donation. They ended up raising $1,330 to bring the total to $1,830. The team selected to donate funds to Crag Rats Search and Rescue, Hood River County Fire & EMS (with funds earmarked for Wildfire Prevention and Urban/Wildfire Interface Evacuation); and the Cascade Locks FISH Food Bank to support families, food pantries, and businesses adversely affected by the fire.

But that wasn't enough for them! This year, the Hillsboro High girls brought a $1,500 donation to our match. These two rival teams have now donated at least $4,000 to fire relief in the Gorge! Our team also spent a day volunteering with Trailkeepers of Oregon.

#Proud2bHRCSD

This message was emailed to May Street Elementary parents this morning and went home with students this afternoon:

Just before 8 am this morning, students and staff at May Street were placed on “lock-out.” A tree on the school grounds caught fire when it came into contact with power lines. Students remained on lock-out until just over 30 minutes later when a fire crew and the power company had secured the scene . A lock-out is called when there is a threat or hazard outside of the school building. Students are held inside of the building and all school activity inside is “business as usual”.

As always, we are grateful to our dedicated first responders who keep our staff and students safe!

At 8 am this morning, one of our buses was at a student stop when a driver in a motor vehicle hit the stopped bus. This took place near Belmont and 22nd street on route 5, bus 15.

We are thankful for a strong partnership with our local first responders, so we can continue to put student safety first in the operations of our district.

post_text:
Happy New Year from HRCSD!

Did you make any New Year’s resolutions? Here are some we can get behind!

1. Attend school on time, every day.
2. Make time to read each day.
3. Try a new activity, club or sport.
4. Set a goal to get good grades. If you're struggling, talk to a teacher.
5. Spend time organizing your calendar and binder.
6. Make your classmates’ day with a daily random act of kindness!
7. Parents, ask your child something specific each evening, like “Who did you hang out with at lunch?” or “What was the best part of your day?” These targeted questions will get a better response and drive a more meaningful conversation.
8. Parents, find a new way to get involved. Volunteer with clubs, sports, site councils, PTOs, SMART reading, tutoring for AVID, etc.

Any other ideas?

As we're seeing Gorge roads and trails open back up, here is a heartfelt story from behind the scenes.

Last year, the Hood River Valley High School girls' soccer match with Hillsboro High was rescheduled due to smoke from the Eagle Creek Fire. At the rescheduled match, Hillsboro surprised our team with a $500 donation to help our community rebuild post fire. Kevin Haspela, our soccer coach, then challenged our girls to double the donation. They ended up raising $1,330 to bring the total to $1,830. The team selected to donate funds to Crag Rats Search and Rescue, Hood River County Fire & EMS (with funds earmarked for Wildfire Prevention and Urban/Wildfire Interface Evacuation); and the Cascade Locks FISH Food Bank to support families, food pantries, and businesses adversely affected by the fire.

But that wasn't enough for them! This year, the Hillsboro High girls brought a $1,500 donation to our match. These two rival teams have now donated at least $4,000 to fire relief in the Gorge! Our team also spent a day volunteering with Trailkeepers of Oregon.

#Proud2bHRCSD

Congratulations to Sandra Piatt, Hood River Valley High School Senior Sandra Piatt. She won a French essay contest (Yes! - an essay in French!) with Scholastic magazines! She challenged herself to refuse and/or reduce her single-use plastic consumption for one week, and wrote about her experience.

Her French teacher Nicole Goode says: “Sandra has a strong work ethic and chooses to be a source of positive energy in the class and greater HRV community. It is incredibly exciting to be celebrating Sandra and her efforts to understand the extent of plastic pollution in our environment and to see her take steps to reduce our negative impact on the planet.”

September 10, 2018 at 1:24 PM ·

A year ago, the kids in Cascade Locks were evacuated by the Eagle Creek fire burning in the Gorge. This summer, we spent the day with 30 kids and visited the charcoal forests along the Pacific Crest Trail.

Like the forests, the kids are young, resilient and full of life.

Please LIKE and SHARE this film with your friends.

Thanks to the wonderful teachers and kids in Cascade Locks for inviting us out to spend the day in the woods. And thanks to Mark Larabee from Pacific Crest Trail Association, Brenna Bell, Mia Pisano and Ember Summer from Bark, Caroline Park from Thunder Island Brewing Company, Aurora Del Val, Hood River News, Apricot Irving and many others for participating in this special day in the woods.
